Funding for #Somalia's New AU Peace Mission Remains Uncertain

#Somalia’s new AU peace mission, AUSSOM, which started in January, is facing significant funding #challenges. 

The mission, replacing ATMIS, aims to support state-building and combat AS  but #financial support remains #unclear. 

A new UN-AU cost-sharing mechanism was meant to cover 75% of the mission's expenses, but delays in its implementation have left funding uncertain for the mission’s first six #months.

The mission's success depends on securing this funding, and a UN Security #Council vote in May is expected to address the issue.

#Political and operational challenges, including regional tensions and troop contributions, also complicate the #situation. 

Despite the creation of a hybrid funding model, the uncertainty of its #application and the shifting priorities of major donors like the US are major concerns for the mission's #future.

question: What can we learn from western strategies to win in business?
tweet_text:
7/50 books for founders
Competing Against Luck: The Story of Innovation and Customer Choice, Clayton M. Christensen et al.

This book introduces the "Jobs to Be Done" (JTBD) theory, emphasizing that customers "hire" products and services to fulfill specific needs or "jobs" in their lives. Understanding these jobs enables businesses to innovate effectively and align their offerings with customer motivations.

Key Concepts:

Jobs to Be Done Theory: This framework posits that customers seek solutions to specific problems or tasks. By identifying these jobs, companies can develop products that truly meet customer needs. 

Functional, Social, and Emotional Dimensions: A job encompasses functional aspects (the practical task), social elements (how the task affects social interactions), and emotional components (the feelings associated with the task). Recognizing all these facets provides a comprehensive understanding of customer motivations.

Customer-Centric Innovation: Focusing on the job rather than the product allows businesses to identify unmet needs and innovate accordingly, leading to solutions that resonate with customers. 

Examples and Case Studies:

McDonald's Milkshake: McDonald's sought to boost milkshake sales by analyzing customer preferences. They discovered that many customers hired the milkshake to make their morning commute more enjoyable and to stave off hunger until lunch. This insight led to product adjustments, such as making the milkshake thicker and adding fruit chunks, enhancing its appeal for the intended job.

Intuit's QuickBooks: Intuit identified that small business owners were using Quicken, a personal finance tool, to manage business finances—a task it wasn't designed for. Recognizing the job of managing business finances, Intuit developed QuickBooks, a solution tailored to this specific need, leading to its success in the market.

Airbnb: Airbnb understood that travelers were seeking more than just a place to stay; they desired authentic, local experiences. By focusing on the job of providing unique travel experiences, Airbnb tailored its platform to connect guests with hosts offering local insights, enhancing the overall travel experience. 

Criticism on JTBD

Overemphasis on Established Needs: Some argue that JTBD is more effective for identifying existing user needs rather than uncovering new, unarticulated ones. This perspective suggests that JTBD may not be as effective in driving innovation for entirely new products or markets. 

Resource Intensiveness: Implementing JTBD research can be time-consuming and resource-intensive. Without adequate commitment, the insights gained may not be robust enough to inform product development effectively.

Potential Oversimplification: Critics like Jared Spool suggest that JTBD might oversimplify user motivations, potentially overlooking the complex, nuanced, and sometimes subconscious reasons behind user behaviors. This simplification could lead to a lack of empathy in product design.

Debate Over Framework Variations: There is ongoing debate about the different interpretations and applications of JTBD. For instance, Alan Klement's version emphasizes emotional aspects of jobs, while others focus on functional components. This divergence has led to confusion and disagreements within the community.

Despite these critiques, many professionals continue to find JTBD a valuable tool for aligning product development with customer needs. The key lies in applying the framework thoughtfully, considering its limitations, and integrating it with other methodologies to achieve a comprehensive understanding of user requirements.

question: What serious challenges do college students face at the end of the semester?
tweet_text:
If you can survive college, you can survive anything.

You walk into college thinking you have it all figured out.

First year? You still believe -
• Good grades = good job.
• Friendships last forever.
• Life will be smooth.

Then, reality slaps you.

 — You apply for so called clubs, internships, committees—rejected, rejected, rejected

— You realize no one cares if you show up. No spoon-feeding. No hand-holding. It’s all on you.

And that’s when college does its real job,
it stops protecting you.

By second year, you start adapting.

— You learn survival. All-nighters, last-minute assignments, bargaining with auto walas like pro or travelling through local buses.

— You understand failure. Rejections don’t break you anymore. You take the L and move on.

— You find real friendships. Not built on convenience, but on “bro, send me the notes” at 1:30 AM.

— You stop waiting for life to get easier. Because it never does. Instead, you get better.

By the time you graduate, you’re not the same person who walked in.

• You’ve been broke, lost, rejected.
• You’ve doubted yourself, struggled, almost given up.
• But you’ve also figured things out, built resilience, and come out stronger.

College doesn’t just give you a degree.

It throws you into chaos, watches you struggle, and then somehow, you make it through.

And that’s when you realize…

You’re unbreakable.

question: How can a pattern of customer feedback help a child learn?
tweet_text:
Does your little one want to hear the same book over and over and over again? 

The repetition can be a little maddening for us as parents, but for children it’s actually very beneficial. 

Favorite books are not only familiar and comforting, but support vocabulary growth and - importantly - your child’s own participation in the reading experience. 

I just love this video of little Theo and his mom as they read Eric Carle’s Does a Kangaroo Have a Mother Too? 

Not only can you tell it’s a book they’ve read together many times, but the familiar, repetitive pattern of the text itself allows Theo to play a role in the reading. 

Watch as he provides an enthusiastic “YES!” at the beginning of each page. 

(Note too what a good job he does at matching his “yes” response to the appropriate point in the text itself. It’s the first thing said after each page is turned.) 

As for vocabulary growth, repeated exposure to new words helps children to
internalize vocabulary more rapidly with one study suggesting that children are more likely to incorporate new vocabulary from a book read three times than from three different books read one time apiece. 

This fantastic little reader was shared to IG by theoriginal_captain.

question: What certain events in history make you wonder how they arrived?
tweet_text:
The pole shift, the floods, and the solar superflare that happened 6,000 years ago have left evidence in the ancient Indus Valley civilization. 

This evidence corroborates the theory of Ben Davidson (Sun Weather Man on X). He says that this cyclical event happens every 12,000 years, with a mini-event (still a mass extinction event) occurring in between, or every 6,000 years.

In fact, on the map in the photo below, in the now desert regions, we had the most advanced ancient cultures, such as the Indus Valley, Egypt, Sumer, the lost Chinese civilizations, and the builders of the Göbekli Tepe and Karahan Tepe temples, among others. All these cultures have legends about the great flood and the evil wind that burned and destroyed everything.

There is evidence that the Indus Valley was flooded and bodies were found in the streets, indicating a quick death, with bodies that were not scavenged by animals. Modern mainstream historians claim that this was a massacre, but there are no visible strike blows from weapons. There are theories of sickness after the flood, but also melted glass was found in the Indus Valley and in Rajasthan, India, suggesting some strong solar event caused the melting and the radiation.

In fact, the evil wind described in the Epic of Gilgamesh, the Sumerian texts, the plagues of Egypt, and the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah can indeed be connected to this large superflare or micronova, as Ben Davidson proposes.

This happened 6,000 years ago, and before that, these deserts were green. It is hard to believe that the most advanced civilizations would choose to live in the deserts. The pyramids and the Sahara were also green. Another pole shift theorist who goes by the name of Ethical Skeptic on X, recently made a very convincing claim that the pyramids were underwater.

The 6,000-year event in the Epic of Gilgamesh is known as the flood of Utnapishtim or the flood of Noah in the Bible. The Hindus have their legends of the flood of Manu, and the ancient Greek flood is called the Flood of Deucalion.

question: Does a third field of data exist, thus enhancing search results?
tweet_text:
LLMs now understand both text and relationships in documents by using knowledge graphs as a bridge.

Knowledge-Aware Retrieval (KAR) framework, proposed in this paper, teaches LLMs to see connections between documents, not just words.

Original Problem 🎯:

Current query expansion methods focus mainly on textual similarities, overlooking important document relations in semi-structured search queries. This leads to suboptimal search results when users have both textual and relational requirements.

-----

Solution in this Paper 🛠️:

• Introduces Knowledge-Aware Retrieval (KAR) framework that augments LLMs with structured document relations from knowledge graphs

• Uses document texts as rich knowledge graph node representations

• Implements document-based relation filtering to extract query-focused relations

• Employs two-step LLM inference: first for entity parsing, then for knowledge-aware expansion

• Constructs document triples combining textual and relational information

-----

Key Insights from this Paper 💡:

• Document texts provide richer node representations than entity names alone

• Structured document relations improve query expansion quality

• Two LLM inferences per query maintain reasonable latency

• Knowledge graphs effectively ground LLM generations to domain-specific facts

-----

Results 📊:

• Outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on AMAZON, MAG, and PRIME datasets

• Achieves better or comparable performance to supervised methods

• Shows consistent improvement across different retrievers (BM25, dense embeddings)

• Maintains practical latency compared to other LLM-based approaches

• Demonstrates effectiveness with both GPT-4 and LLaMA-3.1-8B

question: What insights can a woman share about light within her marriage?
tweet_text:
Six months into marriage, and I can honestly say it’s everything I hoped for and more. Sharing life with my best friend has been such a joy. We never run out of things to talk about, whether it’s late night conversations that last for hours or just cracking up over the most ridiculous stuff. Laughter is truly such an important part of keeping things light and joyful, even during tough times.

But here’s something we’ve learned: the best marriages don’t just happen. They’re built, day by day, with intention. For us, keeping God at the center of our relationship is the MOST important thing. It’s more than just going to Mass together (though that’s huge!) we’ve found that small, intentional habits make a big impact, like praying out loud together before bed, setting spiritual goals, like reading a Catholic book or completing a novena together, making sacrifices for each other in small ways, like offering up a Rosary or fasting for the other person’s intentions (and most of the time not telling each other we're doing it).

Marriage is about helping each other become saints. That’s a big calling, but it’s also so freeing when you know you’re both working toward Heaven, hand in hand.

Now, I've only been married half a year but if I was qualified to give marriage advice it'd be this: never stop learning about each other. Laugh more. Stay curious. Be intentional. And most importantly, invite God into every part of your marriage, even the messy or mundane parts. That’s where His grace works the most!

question: What is the hardest lesson in life that many people get wrong?

That’s the hardest lesson— realizing that some people are so steeped in their own toxicity that wishing them well feels like a betrayal of justice. But carrying that anger, replaying their harm over and over, keeps them lodged inside you. It ties you to them in a way they don’t even deserve.

Letting go isn’t about absolution. It’s about refusing to let their darkness define your inner world. Wishing them peace isn’t saying “I forgive you”— it’s saying “You no longer get to take up space in my mind.”

question: What is the total detail you can actually break down from the search results?
tweet_text:
So, Perplexity just dropped this thing called *Deep Research*—basically an AI-powered overachiever that’s here to shame the way we humans manage Google tabs. Allegedly (and yeah, I say "allegedly" because marketing copy always exaggerates), it can crank out detailed, well-researched reports in 2-4 minutes. Meanwhile, you're still staring blankly at the blinking cursor in a google docs like it owes you rent.  

Here’s the pitch: It handles "expert-level tasks" like finance and marketing research by running *dozens* of searches, synthesizing *hundreds* of sources, and somehow piecing it all together with (what? duct tape and optimism?). You can share the results or save them as PDFs, which is great if you’re the type who insists on keeping digital clutter “organized.”

Freebie users get 5 queries/day—solid if you just want to toy around. But Pro users? 500 queries/day. Unless you're Edward Snowden doing FOIA drills, I don’t know who needs that many, but hey—options.

Should you care? Maybe. Especially since Perplexity is out here bragging they outperformed OpenAI’s comparable tool on something called the "Humanity's Last Exam" benchmark. (21.1% accuracy…I’ll let you decide if that’s impressive or low-key terrifying.) Still, OpenAI beat them on raw score, so let’s not put anyone’s name in lights just yet.

TL;DR:
- Ask questions, get reports in 4 minutes.  
- Flex: Works for topics like product research, marketing, finance.  
- Free for 5 uses/day; Pro lets you go wild with 500/day.   
- Available on the web for now. Apps "coming soon" (translation: probably weeks away).  
 
So—is this the tool we’ve been waiting for or just another shiny object for your productivity graveyard? Guess we’ll find out.

question: In which region is the movement noted by whom?
tweet_text:
My Concerns Regarding the Known 
By Chol Michael Maker 
Thursday, 20 February 2025

I became involved with the Movement at a young age in 1984, a year in which I celebrated my sixteenth birthday on the 24th of November in the bushes. As a teenager, I journeyed through various challenges alongside my group until we arrived in Bor area of Jonglei Province, as it was known at the time. Based on my experiences and observations of the local residents, I have never encountered anything unfamiliar; instead, I felt a strong sense of belonging I could have experienced in Yirol. My cultural identity did not mark me as a stranger; rather, it intertwined with theirs through the rich cultural fabrics of Ciec folklore and traditions. The Equatorians and Bahr el Ghazalians pass through this land, where they enjoy food, drink, and occasionally forge romantic relationships, and during my time there, I have never perceived signs of segregation or derogatory treatment.

However, it is disheartening to witness a growing disregard for the challenges faced by these people who have generously offered their labour, livestock, grains, hospitality, and the numerous amenities enjoyed while traversing their territory. I recall a poignant moment from my time in Bor area. In December 1984, Commander Arok Thon Arok encountered us at Wutror during his travelling from Pibor to Bor and advised us against entering what he termed a “danger zone” due to the ongoing conflict between Anya Nya II and the SPLA in Luo Nuer area. He temporarily halted our progress, and we ultimately continued our journey to Ethiopia, where we arrived at the Itang Refugee Camp before moving on to Bunga, where I received training with the Kazuk Division in 1985. The rest, as they say, is history.

I believe it is now time to repay our debt to the gracious community of Bor. It is time to honour them as we would our own loved ones. We must heed the pleas of the Bor Community and ensure they regain access to the grazing lands for their livestock—lands that once belonged to us all. We have long enjoyed the advantages offered by these animals, yet we now unfairly deny them the freedom to graze. The root of the problem lies with a handful of cattle herders who do not adhere to boundaries that would respect local farming practices.

I do not believe that Governor Louis Lobong incited genocide; rather, he responded to the legitimate concerns of his constituents—the very people he serves and represents. As a political leader, he has a responsibility to champion the protection of his citizens and their property in Eastern Equatoria and should speak out against any violations of his commitments.

Let us exercise patience, fellow citizens, and strive to better distinguish between the various complexities at play. Just as separating grain from chaff is necessary for producing fine flour, so too is it important to navigate our challenges carefully. Since when did cattle rustling transform into a political issue? My fellow people in Yirol have faced similar challenges, enduring regular raids from our neighbours in Adok and Leer in Bentiu area, much like those occurring elsewhere.

The call for calm is far more essential than pitting ourselves against one another. Some of us have restricted access to fellow compatriots who simply seek better pastures for their livestock. I welcome any corrections or insights from those who may understand this matter more fully than I do. I once expressed to someone that the Ambororo nomads traverse the wilderness of South Sudan for water and grazing opportunities, yet we seldom hear about their journeys, which can last several months before they return to their native lands.

Our self-respect should forge connections between our tribes and cultures, serving as a beacon of inspiration for harmonious coexistence as we strive to live together as one nation.

question: How can I catch a million views on my video?
tweet_text:
Want to know the truth about what drives YouTube success? Here’s how I break it down:

1. Packaging: This is the most critical factor. Effective packaging took my videos from an average of 500–1,000 views to regularly hitting 10K, 20K, even 50K views. Your title, thumbnail, and overall presentation set the stage for success.

2. Call to Action: Don’t fear CTAs. Contrary to popular belief, including a call to action won’t get your video suppressed—it’s essential for converting viewers into buyers.

3. Video Length: It’s not about making short videos. What matters is the value you pack into each video. Focus on delivering impactful content, regardless of length.

4. Hook: Your video’s hook should immediately deliver on the promise made in your title and thumbnail. Get to the point quickly and keep your audience engaged from the first second.

5. Editing: Here’s a shocker—most of my videos aren’t heavily edited. Sometimes, keeping it raw and authentic works better than perfecting every cut.

6. Tags: Honestly, tags are the least important. I barely use them, and my channel still thrives.

The takeaway? Focus on the elements that truly impact viewer engagement and conversion, not on the fluff.

question: What did users still discuss at the end of the past year?
tweet_text:
Why Do Many People Want to Be Distracted from Their Own Thoughts with Things Such as Social Media, Music, and Television?

One of my students asked me this question after summarizing the past year of certain events trends, and global occurrences. People have been searching, watching, and engaging with things that, on the surface, may seem significant—politics, elections, and the Olympics, which were among the most discussed topics worldwide over the past year.

At the same time, masses of people were captivated by a pygmy hippo named Mu Deng, born in Thailand. They watched her bathe, smile, and simply exist. They followed the rap feud between Kendrick Lamar and Drake—two artists who once coexisted peacefully but suddenly turned on each other, spilling their rivalry into their music. And people consumed it, eager to witness every insult and every reaction.

Then, there were the advancements of SpaceX, because people still dream of escaping Earth. Dubai chocolate, of all things, also captured global attention, with a milk chocolate pistachio combination garnering billions of views. Meanwhile, wars raged on, both here and in Europe, yet the world’s interest in such matters seemed minimal. Scientific breakthroughs, Nobel Prize winners, and historical moments? Almost completely overlooked.

So how do I summarize this past year? Frankly, it is time to shut it all down.

I do not mean this in a pessimistic way, but I simply don’t see anything solid to base optimism on. Everything is deteriorating. People are drawn to distractions because they have nowhere else to turn. Their personal problems overshadow the world’s crises. When one carries enough personal pain, the suffering of others barely registers.

And so, entertainment dominates. Sports, music, and internet trends are escapes. But even in that, there is a potential turning point. At some stage, after watching enough meaningless content, a person might begin to ask, “Why am I watching this? What am I really searching for?”

That question about the search for meaning holds the key. This will all eventually lead people there. But today, I do not see humanity standing at that threshold. People in general are not evaluating their lives, their mission, or their purpose in a way that would bring them to demand an answer the question about life’s meaning and purpose, to grasp the full picture of creation. Humanity has lost itself.

That is my diagnosis. Many might argue, pointing to various developments or successes, claiming that things are not as bleak as I make them seem. But wait and see. No matter what is added to the mix, in the end, it will dissolve into the same impassable swamp.

If I could direct #humanity to focus on one thing, it would be the meaning of #life . That is the only real question. Everything else is just noise. I rely on the Creator completely—I believe in Him without reservation. And I see no other option. To the Creator, we must give what is His. And to humanity, what remains after He takes His due.

question: What economic trends do you notice in several recent courses?
tweet_text:
some current trends I am seeing:
Auto parts stores prices are very high. I can buy what seems to be a real Nissan part for $30 off line, or, $160 at the local store (and its not marked Nissan). This started around the Covid times and is getting worse. I suspect many are, and have been, taking looses (or close to it) and that many will close down soon. 
Cars have also gotten very "complex". VVT, Turbos, small 4 cylinders. Even in "larger" trucks. this is mostly due to MPG standards. The truck I rented was new, big ol v8 in it, not even cruise on it. Felt very "old school". It also didn't need to meet the same MPG standards. I liked it. I was able to get its MPG average up almost 2 mpg on my trip.
 Such things might seem nit picking. But the other cars, we will see they won't last as long as say a 2008 Camry (not even close).
 While Hybrids tend to (I've never seen one) have those turbo's or 7+ speed autos the battery lifes are still unknown. Chevy built one of the most innovative cars in a long while, the Volt, but people wouldn't buy it (not sure why). 
 The Maverick I bought had a good balance of it all. A N/A 4 cylinder hybrid. 42+ mpg (I could get 62+ out of mine since I understood the inherent flaw in the programing Ford had on it).
 so..what am I saying?
 We are building cars that are way more complex and less reliable that cost more to build and won't resale for the same $ as they won't last as long.
 That brick n mortar auto stores will soon start closing shop. not only is it hard to compete with online, but more complicated engines/transmission won't get the $ spent to 'save' them. 
 I also feel cell phone stores will start closing sooner, rather than later.
 I remember when malls shut down (for the most part) in the 80's. Contractions like this have longer term effects.
 loss of jobs. Real estate revenue, Tax revenue, etc.
 Were we better off with a car that could go 250,000 miles but got slightly worse mpgs? 
 Ok, myth buster here.
I bought ONE new car. 1998 Dodge Stratus with a special motor that got 38mpg and would still do 100+ mph.
 But you had to pay extra to get that motor. Most didn't.
Was also a Dodge.. (eww)...
 I am also seeing things coming here that I ordered via individual delivery drivers, meaning "private" people. Despite making it 98% of the way via the regular folks. one lost $1,400 package (electronics) and by the time they got it sorted I had the replacement. I am reading that a good many "trucking" companies are filing bankruptcy. 
 I think we will also see a housing price drop country wide. I'd been debating selling the last year, wish I had already done it. Best to buy when it crashes, sale before it does.  If I don't meet that, I'll just hold onto what I have and buy when (if) it crashes.
 Which is where I feel we are heading.
And some of this is, imo, fueled by Trump cutting "waste". I write about how some of that waste indeed fuels the economy. If Pelosi doesn't buy a 10K fridge for her Ice cream, then no one sales it. No one ships it. No one installs it. Don't get me wrong, we bought all of that, on a Credit no less (debt). But it still will "shrink" things.
 Cars and homes make up a huge part of the economy. Take out the auto parts stores, the used car lots, etc, and you leave buildings open, lots open.
 You will find few people wanting a 10 year old Prius. Fact.
 But a 10 year old Civic or Camry or Tacoma, all day long if its in great shape.
 A 10 year old Maverick? nope. Car is cheap ass made.
 Combine this with Congress having a hard time selling us on a "bailout" package (debt).
 So, what am I really saying?
 When it happens, instead, figure out what I am really saying here.
 Turn the narrative on what can be, not what was.
Unburden ourselves on what was.
 Car wise we should mostly be driving EV's or Hybrids. We should shun turbo Tacoma's with 4 cylinders (or Fords/GM's/Chryslers). We should expect cars to last 10-15 years. not 10 or less. 
 You can't find a decent made diesel (at all) now a days. at best "meh". Sure the power is there. But gone are the days of 500+K diesel trucks. (mostly) that cost little to upkeep.
 Should we go back to those? 
My 2003 VW diesel was among the best made, or, will be made.
We are not going back though.
My take on a few of the current trends I see going on. Things that are about to change. Lots of street corner auto parts stores going to close in the next 5 years.
 Lots of cell phone retail places.
Who will occupy those places? Those jobs?
 How will the housing market fair if we do export 10,000,000+ people who didn't come here legally (filling out a form falsely is not legal).
OK, the upside. If Trump gets rid of the DOE and sends the funds directly to local schools and increases the funds due to less overhead, how does that play out? I just read and the 2018 DOE staff size was about 4K people. Seems "small". But is it? What do they do? That is MORE than 1 employee per U.S county. Now it doesn't seem so "small" eh? IMO if schools get the $ directly it should be allocated via Congress thru specific reasons and if abused the DOJ should handle it, not the DOE.
 to harp on that subject Bullying was a problem when I was in school. I read this A.M about how my local small school has sever bullying going on. Many saying the school admin doesn't give 2 shits about it. As I see it Congress should only care about test results and discrimination in schools. bullying is, discrimination of sorts. if anything metrics should be established there. A good "Census" question. "was my child bullied in a Government funded K-12 school" If a district hits a certain % should the DOJ not get involved? What does it say that we put NO effort on solving that? I know my kids (learned this after the fact) were bullied in school.
 But this is a larger social issue.
All of it is a social issue.
 One we often let Politicians divide us over.
The key takeaway here is we are about to see the effects of what Trump is doing on a local level. I already see other factors in play. how we let the narrative play out will make the next 20 years turn out one way, or the other.
 I know if done right my house, in time, value will go up.
 But if you own a house in D.C it might not!

question: What new class of growth strategies has emerged recently?
tweet_text:
Where does your agency fit? 

The Experimentation Agency Growth Quadrant

Not all experimentation agencies scale the same way. Some dominate strategy, some get stuck in execution, and others struggle to break free from tough markets and price pressure.

Our latest research—based on nearly 40 interviews and a survey —reveals five distinct agency growth paths.

🟡 Generalisation, Execution Work, Price Pressure → Small agencies often diversify to survive but find it hard to get leads and high value work. Clients see them as execution vendors rather than trusted experimentation partners.

🔵 Execution Specialisation, Scaled Process, Efficiency → Some agencies scale rapidly by refining execution, but without differentiation, they remain trapped in process-driven growth rather than moving into high-value strategy.

🟢 Specialisation, Niche or High Value, Limited Scalability → High-trust agencies focus on deep expertise—personalization, advanced analytics, or experimentation strategy—but find it difficult to grow.

🔴 Ecosystem Leadership, Experimentation Transformation, Strategic Influence → The most successful agencies do less execution work. They lead vendor partnerships, shape industry best practices, and own the experimentation roadmap for their clients. They aren’t running tests, they’re changing how organisations run tests.

⚫ Flawless Execution Specialisation, → These agencies don’t pivot to strategy but become the best in their market at execution. They aren’t just running tests; they are trusted experts for complex, high-stakes experimentation. Their technical excellence and reliability make them indispensable to enterprise clients.

💡 The Big Takeaway?

🔹 Small agencies struggle with price pressure and commoditization
🔹 Mid-sized agencies can get stuck in execution work
🔹 Large agencies win by owning strategy
🔹 The agencies leading the industry transform experimentation itself

📊 Curious where your agency fits? Drop a comment below! And if you want to see the full breakdown, wait for our report - it’s coming in April!

question: What key factors influence a million-dollar situation in tech startups?
tweet_text:
.@rabois Breaks Down the Art of Identifying Mispriced Talent 

"Fundamentally, when you start a startup, you're like one to two people sitting in a proverbial garage, and you have to compete with talent with OpenAI or Google or Meta or Apple or Nvidia. And so, you have to have some advantage, some comparative advantage. The mispriced talent is almost surely the most, most appropriate advantage you can sort of create and forge. It's difficult, but, like at a conceptual level, you're looking for talent that these large companies just don't know how to process accurately.

So, lack of data points—I like the legible concept. If someone's very young and early in their career, they may not have enough data points to read. So you find a 19-year-old—you know, does Google know how to assess a 19-year-old? Are there enough data points? Maybe not.

Second thing is, most large companies, not all but most, become sort of homogeneous in their hiring process. And so, people who have disruptive characteristics break the mold. Those people can be very, very, very high leverage. So if you identify people who have, like, a screw loose somewhere, a standard homogeneous hiring process where everybody has an effective veto will tend to eliminate those people too. So you can identify those types of people.

You can sometimes find geo, geographic talent. That's become more difficult in the last 10 years than 20 or 30 years ago, where there are places that large companies aren't looking. I think that's a lot less common and available now, but 20 years ago, you probably could create geographic arbitrage. But you should be able to isolate, at a minimum, if a founder is—why do I have some alpha here that other people are going to miss?

It could be also historical experience. Like, for example, if you've known someone for 15 years, perhaps you have data points that aren't going to show up on a LinkedIn profile, that aren't going to be processed in a standard hiring process. So that can be a competitive advantage too. It's hard to scale that—almost nobody has relationships, you know, over X period of time with enough people to scale a company—but, selectively, that could be very strategic."

question: How does a friend live with the burden of past suffering?
tweet_text:
#EsztersArticle #9

GRIEF — THE EMOTIONAL MARIANA TRENCH

Many believe that grief and the grieving process enter a person’s life only when a significant person or a beloved pet dies. However, we can feel grief due to the loss of many things in various ways.

For instance, when we lose our job, when a tree under which we used to sit with our father is cut down, or even after a tough childhood, we grieve for the happy childhood we never had. The intensity of pain varies, but the stages of grief remain consistent.

What should we expect during these times?

It’s worth knowing the emotional roller-coaster we might experience when we lose someone or something significant to us.

In my life, I’ve lost important people several times. After my grandparents, my partner also fell ill and left at the age of 28.

I can imagine how painful it is for those preparing to depart, unable to further help, love, or protect those they leave behind. This pain is equally shared by those who stay, who couldn’t assist, heal, or save. Having experienced this multiple times, I can confidently say it’s a hellish situation. Months of battling, oscillating between hope and despair, unavoidable conversations about death and the aftermath, and the profound pain of love torments both sides.

We all know that life on Earth continues after death. Those left behind cannot give up, but those departing wish to know for certain that their loved ones will be alright.

Grief is a lengthy process

Those attempting to shorten or suppress it will undoubtedly face severe challenges and prolonged pain. You have to traverse through it, experiencing every terrible and good moment. Surprisingly, there are plenty of the latter. For me, it took two years to process everything, navigating through each phase of grief sequentially…

First, the shock…

I was very polite to the empathetic paramedics when they said there was nothing left to do, but once they left, I stared blankly for long minutes.

Then, control…

I handled everything super efficiently. I never thought there would be so many details to consider for a funeral or the variety of urns to choose from. I got particularly irritated when selecting lace doilies. Who cares about the lace covering the urn???

Then came anger…

I remember pressing the quick dial on my phone, calling his number, even though I knew his mobile was off in the drawer at home. I shouted and cried in the car, cursing everything and everyone that came to mind. Some days were better, others infinitely worse, oscillating for months.

Then, goodbye and separation…

I spent much time alone, conversing with him by a white candle for hours. I revisited old photos and cried. A lot. Slowly, I began to feel how lucky I was to have known him and been loved by him, albeit in his introverted manner.

It was a tough two years, but now, I can love my husband wholeheartedly because pieces of my heart aren’t stuck in the past. For this, I’m eternally grateful.

To move forward after such a profound loss, I believe one must let themselves immerse in the pain. Deeply, agonizingly, and let themselves truly reach the bottom of the pit. Well, pit? Rather, the Mariana Trench. Only from there, and nowhere else, can one rebound. As long as one clings desperately to the steep cliffs of the trench, fearing the impending pain, starting anew is impossible. There’s no momentum to harness.

This awaits all of us who remain. I hope we have the courage to let ourselves sink into the pain and the strength to push off from the trench’s bottom when we’re ready!

– Eszter

question: What significant story do you want to share, whatever it may be?
tweet_text:
His father put his small hand on the table and cut off his pinky finger. 

He was just 2 years old.

He ended up bouncing around in foster care for a few years and then landed in a specialized educational program for children with severe behavior disorders.

He was one of my first students in my first ever class. My first two years of teaching was actually in all hearing self-contained classroom. I had to use my voice/speech. It was very challenging for me, obviously.

Years later I got an email at work. He had tracked me down. Would I like a card? I’m invited! In that email it was explained to me that I had told him that I believed in him. I did not remember it, at all, but he did.

I was invited to his college graduation!

I was/amSO proud of him- not necessarily for finishing school, for eventually becoming a doctor… I’m so proud that in spite of his horrendous struggles- he thrived. 

Did I fly across the country to watch him graduate? You bet.

question: What drives good human behavior behind social media interactions?
tweet_text:
Get anyone to say yes…

1. Reciprocity: Give first, get without asking. Offer value upfront (a tip, a favor), and people feel compelled to return it.  

2. Commitment & Consistency: People strive to match their actions to their promises. Get a small yes now, and bigger ones follow.  

3. Social Proof: We look to others for cues. Show people doing it (testimonials, trends), and others jump in.  

4. Liking: We agree with those we like. Build rapport (compliment, connect, mirror) and watch trust grow.  

5. Authority: Expertise wins trust. Flash credentials or let others vouch for you; people defer to the knowledgeable.  

6. Scarcity: Less equals more desire. Highlight whats rare or time-limited, and urgency kicks in.  

Each year I read “Influence” by Cialdini and always come away with more notes.

question: What plan could improve engagement on those specific pages?
tweet_text:
You're Creating Content in Web3… But You're Doing It All Wrong.

And you're not alone.

Most people want to grow but they’re playing the content game completely wrong.

They think posting more = growing more. 

But…

❌ No one remembers them.
❌ No real audience connection.
❌ No trust, no opportunities.

Why?

Because they’re following bad content strategies. 

Here’s what’s really holding you back:

1️⃣ Beyond engagement, make impact.

Everyone wants engagement, but here’s the truth: 

Engagement ≠ Impact.

From what I noticed and I'm sure you have noticed it too.

Post like Giveaways, Gm get 2x more likes and retweets than educational or insightful content.

But guess what? 

Those same viral posts have 40% lower retention rates meaning people engage once and never come back.

Your goal isn’t to get likes. It’s to make people remember you.

Look at these threads written by @netrovertHQ
@Ernestofweb3 

https://t.co/p88wEpXbfE

https://t.co/cF701spvzi

https://t.co/AiBAFPUyn3

https://t.co/9uasg61uhE

https://t.co/Nskz9021OK

Alot of people go back to read it and still refer people to go and read their threads.

2️⃣ Sounding Like Everyone Else.

If you sound like everyone else, you’re replaceable.

If I see @Ifee_lovee I will definitely know, look at her post about oracle network this morning.

The intro alone is 🔥🔥.

Same thing with @KayDCopywriter , the way she writes, weaves her words, the flow.

Best copywriter out there.

If I see @xanianthegreat and @Pretoria01 I will definitely know. The storytelling and hook alone😂😂🔥

If your content could be posted by 100 other people, you’re invisible.

Inject your personality. 

Have opinions.

Make people feel something when they read your content.

Generic content doesn’t stick.

Share your unique take.

→ If you’re a dev, break down complex concepts simply.

→ If you trade, show a real mistake you made and what you learned.

→ If you’re a founder, talk about your struggles, not just wins.

3️⃣ Posting Without a Content Funnel.

The biggest mistake? No structure.

Most people post randomly and hope something sticks. But top creators have a system.

Think of your content like a funnel:

🔹 Top of Funnel (TOFU) → Entertaining, curiosity-driven posts to attract attention.
🔹 Middle of Funnel (MOFU) → Educational content to position you as an expert.
🔹 Bottom of Funnel (BOFU) → Personal experiences, deep insights, and offers.

Most people stop at TOFU. And that’s why their audience never sticks around.

4️⃣ Not Engaging With Their Audience.

Web3 isn’t just content. It’s community.

Yet, 90% of people in this space just post and ghost. 

No replies. No discussions. No relationship-building.

But here’s the thing:
→ The highest-converting posts (DMs, collabs, job offers) don’t come from likes they come from conversations.

Want proof? Check your DMs.

So How Do You Actually Grow?

✅ Be original. Share insights no one else is talking about.
✅ Think beyond virality. Focus on impact, not hype.
✅ Engage like CRAZY, but do it strategically because of Mr landlord 😂

Talk to people, comment, and build relationships.
✅ Structure your content. Don’t post aimlessly, build a system.

That’s how you actually grow.

Geeeeeeeemmmmmm People.

question: How is technology an important player in moving society forward?
tweet_text:
Achieving the pinnacle of human development across all fields requires more than just AI technology. While AI is a transformative tool, its integration with broader societal, ethical, and systemic frameworks is essential. Here's a structured breakdown of the necessary components:

1. Ethical Governance and Responsibility
   - Bias and Fairness: Addressing algorithmic biases to ensure equitable outcomes.  
   - Privacy and Autonomy: Safeguarding data rights and preventing surveillance overreach.  
   - Accountability: Establishing clear guidelines for AI decision-making and liability.  

2. Human-Centric Collaboration  
   - Interdisciplinary Synergy: Combining AI with expertise in fields like medicine, education, and ecology.  
   - Creativity and Empathy: Leveraging uniquely human traits for innovation and ethical judgment.  
   - Inclusive Design: Engaging diverse communities in AI development to reflect global needs.  

3. Infrastructure and Policy  
   - Digital Equity: Bridging the access gap to technology and computational resources.  
   - Regulatory Frameworks: Creating laws for AI safety, transparency, and public benefit.  
   - Global Cooperation: Harmonizing standards through international bodies (e.g., UN, WHO).  

4. Sustainability and Ecology  
   - Green AI: Prioritizing energy-efficient algorithms and renewable energy use.  
   - Environmental Stewardship: Deploying AI to monitor ecosystems and optimize resource use.  

5. Education and Accessibility  
   - Lifelong Learning: Preparing populations for AI-driven economies via reskilling programs.  
   - Universal Access: Democratizing AI tools to reduce inequality and empower marginalized groups.  

6. Cultural and Social Adaptation  
   - Cultural Sensitivity: Tailoring AI applications to respect local values and norms.  
   - Social Safety Nets: Addressing job displacement through policies like UBI or adaptive welfare systems.  

7. Philosophical and Visionary Leadership
   - Defining "Progress": Aligning AI with humanistic goals (e.g., well-being, equity) rather than purely economic metrics.  
   - Long-Term Ethics: Encouraging dialogue on AI’s role in shaping humanity’s future.  

8. Security and Stability  
   - Cybersecurity: Protecting AI systems from malicious attacks and misuse.  
   - Risk Mitigation: Developing global treaties to prevent AI-driven conflict or arms races.  

9. Health and Psychological Well-being
   - Complementary Care: Using AI to enhance, not replace, human-centric healthcare.  
   - Mental Health: Monitoring AI’s societal impact on stress, loneliness, and self-perception.

question: What sense do you get about summer trends in land use?
tweet_text:
We've been searching for acreage in Virginia the last few months. One thing I am disturbed to see is the trend of "Conservation Easements." 

Like all things technocratic in agenda, this seems like a good thing from afar, until you realize they are locking up millions upon millions of acres at an alarming rate.  

The idea is that we are gently squeezed out of rural areas, into cities before the year 2100.

If you buy a property with an easement on it, not only are you usually not allowed to build anything on it, it must be trees or whatever, in perpetuity. Apparently it is possible, yet extremely difficult to get something like this reversed.

I'm sure the assumption is that people would be turning things into pasture to monocrop corn or soy...But what if I wanted to run sheep regeneratively on 30 acres? If you were REALLY interested in conservation, you'd look at #regenerativeagriculture

Instead I see tree farm after tree farm, and LOTS of dusty, degraded soil. You're not doing nature any favors by harvesting trees once every 20 years and replanting.  That teensy little deer poop isn't gonna feed 120 acres of pine. 

I'd love to see Conservation easements reassessed and responsible farmers graze animals over these lands and raise food and goods for hungry humans.

question: How do religious beliefs shape our understanding of reality moving forward?

Though not religious,I have always respected the role the word of god and the Aspect of gods existence plays in our lives. A higher moral authority that cuts across all topics and ways of living unquestionably because its god who demands it and he knows better. And this is why Pastors will tell you not to question it. 

The moment we start questioning it,and the moment we decide to abandon god and his words,alot of things fall out of place. Like morality,Truth,virtues,vices etc will now transition from being objective to subjective. People start creating their own scales of morality. Man will try to become his own god. But he cant,he'll only go astray. 

A woman will kill her unborn child and say she has the right to do so,its her body. A man will have sex with his neighbors wife and justify himself by saying she told him she doesn't love her husband. A rich man will steal a poor mans land and say the poor man wasn't doing anything with it. All these things god has either classified them as right or wrong. But man has decided to create his own virtues and vices.

By killing god man unknowingly returns to his barbaric form which he claimed to have evolved from. Naangalianga my nephew alfayo nasema haka kalibahatika sana,his mother got pregnant when she was in very bad state,very bad,both financially and mentally. Alikua hali mbaya saidi. She wanted to flash him out,mimi nikamwambia ni sawa,and her sisters also agreed. But the mother found out what she was planning warned her,akamwambia Cecilia usijaribu kuua mtoto. Usiniletee laana kwa hii boma. She said it was wrong. Wewe kama utashindwa zaa uniletee. 

7 years down the line Afayo is the best thing that happened to her. You casually see her smiling when she sees him running around with his faded navy blue underwear,haka kaliponea chupi chupi aki. We must not abandon god. Not because we want to go to heaven but because,god is what keeps us together as a species. Otherwise the only kumi bila break Ruto will expirience is inthe dungeon we will throw him in kule shimo la tewa for the pain he has brought us. Kasia ya mtu!

1. Deep engagement (DMs, replies, profile visits) – The gold standard

2. Light engagement (likes, retweets, bookmarks) – Good, but needs volume

3. Passive engagement (read time, scroll pauses) – Invisible, but crucial

What does this mean?

Threads win because they boost read time → more time on X = more reach

DM worthy tweets get pushed higher because private shares = highest trust

Focus on depth.

question: What is the nature of low treatment options available late in the process?
tweet_text:
NEJM Perspective*  highlights that new treatments for serious illnesses, like ALS and cancer, are sometimes approved before there’s strong proof they work!!! This can leave patients paying high out-of-pocket costs for drugs that might not help. 

For example, the ALS drug Relyvrio cost patients about $150,000 per year but was later withdrawn when studies showed it didn’t improve outcomes. The FDA doesn’t consider drug prices when approving treatments, so patients often face financial hardship, sometimes turning to crowdfunding to afford medications. 

So, we need clearer FDA labeling, regulating drug prices, and capping patient costs to prevent financial strain from treatments with uncertain benefits…

question: What big statement can you make about the course of trends?
tweet_text:
Here’s a comprehensive overview of the latest technology trends as of 2025, based on current developments and projections:
1. Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML)
AI remains a dominant force in technology, with significant advancements in natural language processing, computer vision, and generative AI. These innovations are powering applications like personalized recommendations, autonomous systems, and intelligent assistants. Meanwhile, machine learning models are becoming more efficient, requiring less data and computational power, making AI more accessible across industries.
2. Quantum Computing
Quantum computing is progressing rapidly, with companies like IBM and Google leading the charge toward quantum supremacy. These machines promise to tackle complex problems—such as cryptography, materials science, and optimization—that classical computers struggle to solve. While still in its early stages, quantum computing is poised to revolutionize multiple fields.
3. Blockchain and Decentralized Finance (DeFi)
Beyond cryptocurrencies, blockchain technology is finding applications in supply chain management, digital identity, and smart contracts. Decentralized Finance (DeFi) is also on the rise, enabling lending, borrowing, and trading without traditional intermediaries, transforming the financial landscape.
4. 5G and Beyond
The widespread rollout of 5G networks is delivering faster internet speeds, lower latency, and enhanced connectivity. This is fueling advancements in the Internet of Things (IoT), autonomous vehicles, and smart cities. Meanwhile, research into 6G is already underway, hinting at even more transformative capabilities in the near future.
5. Internet of Things (IoT)
IoT devices are everywhere—from smart home appliances to industrial sensors. When paired with AI, IoT systems can predict maintenance needs, optimize energy usage, and improve user experiences, creating a more connected and intelligent world.
6. Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR)
AR and VR technologies are maturing, with applications spanning gaming, education, healthcare, and remote work. The rise of Mixed Reality (MR) is blending physical and digital environments, offering more immersive and interactive experiences.
7. Cybersecurity
As technology evolves, so do cyber threats. Cybersecurity is a top priority, with innovations like AI-driven threat detection, zero-trust architectures, and quantum-resistant cryptography helping to safeguard data and systems against increasingly sophisticated attacks.
8. Sustainable Technology
There’s a growing focus on sustainable tech, driven by regulatory pressures and consumer demand. This includes energy-efficient data centers, renewable energy integration, and eco-friendly manufacturing processes, all aimed at reducing the environmental impact of technology.
9. Biotechnology and Health Tech
Biotechnology is transforming healthcare with breakthroughs in genomics, CRISPR, and personalized medicine. Additionally, wearable health devices and telemedicine platforms are advancing, providing real-time monitoring and remote care options.
10. Edge Computing
Edge computing is bringing data processing closer to where it’s generated, reducing latency and bandwidth usage. This trend is critical for real-time applications like autonomous vehicles and industrial automation, enabling faster and more efficient systems.
Shaping the Future
These trends are driving innovation across industries such as healthcare, finance, manufacturing, and beyond. They’re creating new opportunities for businesses, enhancing consumer experiences, and addressing global challenges like sustainability and security. As these technologies continue to evolve, they’ll shape the future of how we live, work, and interact with the world.

question: What scenes offer insight into how people suffer online?
tweet_text:
MENTAL HEALTH & MISUNDERSTANDING AND PUBLIC DRAGS

After having my account suspended and being forced to start over, I thought I’d seen it all. But few hours ago, I experienced firsthand how quickly misunderstandings can escalate in the Web3 space.

During a recent Twitter Space I hosted, one of our guest speakers was unintentionally removed from the speaker role. Unfortunately, this led to me being publicly accused of something completely against my values—cyberbullying and racism. Worse still, I was labeled a "cancer to Web3."

In moments like this, I can’t help but feel the weight of the space's challenges. Ironically, having a smaller account might have helped contain the situation, but the emotional toll remains. Web3 is built on principles of decentralization, collaboration, and innovation. Yet, like any community, misunderstandings happen. How we handle them reflects our maturity as a space.

🔹 The Mental Health Impact of Public Dragging
Public call-outs and dragging are more than just online noise—they have real mental health impacts. Behind every username is a human being with emotions, responsibilities, and a genuine desire to contribute positively. False accusations, especially those targeting someone's character, can lead to stress, anxiety, and burnout—issues we’ve seen repeatedly in Web3.

🔹 Let's Normalize Constructive Conversations
As Web3 continues to evolve, let’s grow alongside it. Rather than rushing to public accusations, let’s normalize reaching out privately to seek clarity. Misunderstandings can often be resolved with a simple DM. This shift alone can prevent unnecessary harm and foster more trust within the community.

🔹 Accountability with Empathy
Accountability matters—but empathy should never be overlooked. We can address issues without dehumanizing each other. Words are powerful. They can either support or shatter someone’s mental state. Let’s choose wisely.

To anyone who’s ever been on the receiving end of false accusations or public harassment: you are not alone. Mental health deserves the same attention as technological innovation in Web3. Let’s build a space where misunderstandings lead to conversations, not character assassination.

GM GM

question: Did I cut all the right keywords for my search?
tweet_text:
AI search results aren’t reproducible. Manual searches are a nightmare. 

The solution? AI-assisted keyword strategies.

If you’re conducting a systematic literature search, you can’t rely on AI-driven search engines. You still need keyword-based search strategies—which can be complex and time-consuming.

Most researchers struggle with this.

But there’s a solution: ChatGPT can help.

Use the prompt below, refine it as needed, and get a solid starting point for your search strategy. (adapted from Wang et al. 2023)

👇 Copy, paste, and adapt.

---------------------
You are a academic search expert, who collaborates and helps researchers and physician-scientists in an academic institution.

Take a deep breath and let’s do this step-by-step.
Step 1: Produce a list of 50 "relevant" terms.

Follow my instructions precisely to develop a highly effective Boolean query for a medical systematic review literature search. Do not explain or elaborate. Only respond with exactly what I request. First, Given the following research question or topic, please identify 50 terms or phrases that are relevant. The terms you identify should be used to retrieve more relevant studies, so be careful that the terms you choose are not too broad. You are not allowed to have duplicates in your list. statement: [insert research question]

Step 2: Classify terms into three categories using PICOT

For each item in the list you created in step 1, classify it into as of three categories: terms relating to health conditions (A), terms relating to a treatment (B), terms relating to types of study design (C). When an item does not fit one of these categories, mark it as (N/A). Each item needs to be categorised into (A), (B), (C), or (N/A)

Step 3: Create a Boolean Query in PubMed Syntax.

Using the categorised list you created in step 2, create a Boolean query that can be submitted to PubMed which groups together items from each category. For example: ((itemA1[Title/Abstract] OR itemA2[Title/Abstract] or itemA2[Title/Abstract]) AND (itemB1[Title/Abstract] OR itemB2[Title/Abstract] OR itemB3[Title/Abstract]) AND (itemC1[Title/Abstract] OR itemC2[Title/Abstract] OR itemC3[Title/Abstract]))

Step 4: Refine search strategy and add relevant MeSH.

Use your expert knowledge to refine the query, making it retrieve as many relevant documents as possible while minimising the total number of documents retrieved. Also add relevant MeSH terms into the query where necessary, e.g., MeSHTerm[MeSH]. Retain the general structure of the query, however, with each main clause of the query corresponding to a PICO element. The final query still needs to be executable on PubMed, so it should be a valid query.
----------------------------------

"3 Core Strategies for Clinical Researchers: Effortlessly Craft & Design Great Research Using AI & Open-Access Tools"

question: How do you choose natural language processing for your work decisions?
tweet_text:
What is NLP?
Natural language processing (NLP) is a subfield of computer science and artificial intelligence (AI) that uses machine learning to enable computers to understand and communicate with human language.
NLP enables computers and digital devices to recognize, understand and generate text and speech by combining computational linguistics—the rule-based modeling of human language—together with statistical modeling, machine learning and deep learning.
NLP research has helped enable the era of generative AI, from the communication skills of large language models (LLMs) to the ability of image generation models to understand requests. NLP is already part of everyday life for many, powering search engines, prompting chatbots for customer service with spoken commands, voice-operated GPS systems and question-answering digital assistants on smartphones such as Amazon’s Alexa, Apple’s Siri and Microsoft’s Cortana.
NLP also plays a growing role in enterprise solutions that help streamline and automate business operations, increase employee productivity and simplify business processes.

question: What key strategies can a worker use to achieve their goals?
tweet_text:
The Productivity Box: From To-Do Lists to Goal Oriented Performance

When it comes to managing your time at work, you’re often trapped in a relentless loop of ticking off daily tasks. Yet, shifting focus toward goal oriented performance rather than mere checklists can unlock substantial progress and align efforts with what genuinely drives  long-term success.

It’s pretty clear  that to-do lists are undeniably useful at work. By breaking tasks into manageable steps, they reduce overwhelm, foster organization, and ensure  critical deadlines aren’t overlooked.

However, to-do lists alone won’t guarantee progress. Goals cut through that noise. They tie today’s work to tomorrow’s vision. Prioritize what matters, not just what’s urgent. While to-do lists focus on what needs to be done, goals answer to why it matters.

Goals in our work serve as a guiding compass, ensuring effort is directed toward outcomes that drive real progress. Here are a couple of steps you should follow in this process:

1⃣ Identify your core objectives
Reflect on your short-term ambitions and long-term visions. 

2⃣ Categorize your goals
Not  all goals carry equal weight across areas of your work life. Group them  into categories. Categorization reveals where you’re over-investing  time or neglecting key areas.

3⃣ Set SMART goals
🔸 Specific -> Launch an online boutique selling eco-friendly apparel.
🔸 Measurable –> Secure 5 suppliers and finalize a 20-product catalog by month 2.
🔸 Achievable –> Begin with a limited product line to test demand, using savings under $10k.
🔸 Relevant –> Align with my mission to promote sustainable fashion alternatives.
🔸 Time-bound –> Soft-launch the website by month 4; full launch by month 6.

4⃣ Prioritize your goals
Not  every goal needs immediate attention. Rank them using urgency and  impact. For example, a product update with a 6-month deadline may result  in a steep reorganization of your to-do lists.

5⃣ Break down big goals into smaller ones
Ambitious goals—such as launching a business—can feel overwhelming, stalling momentum before progress even begins. 

To avoid this, set realistic expectations that align with your capacity, ensuring steady improvement in productivity.

By focusing on your goals you’ll be able to:
🔹 Increase your sense of purpose
🔹 Improve your productivity
🔹 Reduce stress

Your to-do list might include tasks like:
👉 Researching market trends
👉 Creating a business plan
👉 Building a website
👉 Networking with potential clients

Goals  redefine the idea of productivity. They anchor your work in a larger vision, turning fragmented efforts into intentional progress.

⚠️  While to-do lists keep you occupied, it is goals that provide true  direction. And that sense of purpose, not mere busyness, fuels lasting  productivity and success ⚠️

Read the entire article here: https://t.co/W5mQzDtWzr

#goals #performance #taskmanagement #Productivity #ProductivityHacks #todo

question: How does gas trade impact global energy power dynamics?
tweet_text:
🚀 Natural Gas Surges Above $4.2 – Setting New Highs for 2025! 🔥

Natural gas has recently printed two powerful bullish daily candles, propelling prices above the $4.2 level, marking a new high for the year. This upward momentum is underpinned by several macroeconomic factors:

🌡️ Arctic Blast Drives Demand

An intense Arctic blast has gripped central and eastern U.S., leading to a surge in heating demand. The severe cold has not only increased consumption but also caused production challenges due to “freeze-offs,” where wells are temporarily out of service. This combination has tightened supply and pushed prices higher.

🌐 Global Supply Concerns

The expiration of a key gas transit deal between Russia and Ukraine has disrupted traditional supply routes to Europe. This shift has intensified competition for liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports, as European countries seek alternative sources to meet their energy needs, thereby influencing global natural gas prices.

🏛️ Policy and Infrastructure Developments

In response to heightened demand and potential shortages, policymakers are taking action. For instance, New York has approved permits to expand natural gas infrastructure, aiming to ensure adequate supply during peak demand periods. Such decisions, while sometimes controversial, reflect the pressing need to address immediate energy requirements.

🔮 Market Outlook

The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) has revised its natural gas price forecasts, anticipating that the Henry Hub spot price will average $3.80 per million British thermal units (MMBtu) in 2025, up from previous estimates. This adjustment reflects the current market dynamics of increased demand and constrained supply.

As natural gas prices climb, it’s crucial for consumers and businesses to stay informed and consider strategies to manage potential cost impacts.

What are your thoughts on the current natural gas market trends? Share your insights below!

question: What interesting behavior can be observed on this site in your state?
tweet_text:
I was pulling up to our church to pick up and drop off some donated items for hurricane relief. It was 1pm or so in the afternoon on a week day.

As I pulled through the drive to our church office, a doe stood in the middle of the road with twin fawns. I stopped the car, and she slowly walked toward my driver door. I put my window down and she stood there about 8 feet from me for many seconds, probably close to a minute. Her twin fawns ran around and played in front of my car.

I started talking to the doe, and the fawns startled at the sound of my voice and ran to her. She sniffed them both and then quietly walked into the woods with her fawns calmly following.

question: How can I arrive at content that beats less popular videos?
tweet_text:
You don’t need personal success to create valuable content.

If you want to create content but you feel stuck because you haven’t “made it” yet, here’s the truth:

You just need insight, research, and a fresh angle.

—

Here’s how to add value- even if you don’t feel like an expert yet:

1. Become a Curator of Great Ideas

You don’t have to be the one who did it.

You just have to be the one who shares it.

→ Break down business case studies
→ Analyze trends and strategies
→ Reverse-engineer what’s working

🔹 Example:

• How Gymshark Built a Billion-Dollar Brand Using Limited Drops
• Why Peloton Pivoted & What We Can Learn

You’re not pretending to be an expert. You’re a researcher bringing insights to your audience.

2. Synthesize What Others Don’t Have Time For

People don’t have time to dig through books, podcasts, and long reports.

Make it easier for them.

🔹 Example:

• I Watched 5 Alex Hormozi Videos- Here’s What They All Have in Common
• I Read 10 Business Biographies- This Was the #1 Pattern

You’re saving people time. And that’s valuable.

3. Document, Don’t Teach

You don’t have to be the expert.

You can be the person figuring things out.

🔹 Example:

• I’m Starting From Scratch on LinkedIn-  Here’s What’s Working After 30 Days
• My First Attempt at Cold Email- What I Learned From 20 Rejections

People relate to the process.

And they root for those who are actively figuring things out.

4. Make Your Content Actionable

Instead of saying, “Here’s what worked for me,”
Say, “I analyzed 100 successful people- here’s what they have in common.”

🔹 Example:

• 5 Viral Hook Formulas I Found Studying the Top 100 LinkedIn Posts
• 3 Ways to Structure a LinkedIn Post That Drives Engagement

If you break things down into steps people can use, you become valuable- without needing personal success.

5. Reverse-Engineer What’s Already Working

Instead of trying to create from scratch, analyze what’s working and explain it.

🔹 Example:

• Why Glossier Succeeded Without Traditional Advertising
• How Warby Parker Disrupted the Eyewear Industry

You’re not making bold claims.

You’re explaining proven success.

6. Share a Perspective, Not Just Advice

You don’t have to teach.

Just start the right conversations.

🔹 Example:

• Everyone Talks About Personal Branding, But Here’s What They’re Missing…
• Most Entrepreneurs Think X… But What If The Real Answer Is Y?

Good content isn’t about what you know.

It’s about how you think.

—

Final Thought:

You don’t need more success.

You need more insight.

If you curate, synthesize, document, and reverse-engineer the right things…

Your audience will see you as valuable- whether you’re “successful” yet or not.

question: How can I break off enough time for my role in content creation?
tweet_text:
Most businesses struggle with content creation because they’re doing it the hard way.

You sit down, try to think of an idea, create a post, record a video, and then… repeat the cycle every single day.

But what if you could turn 1 hour of effort into 30+ content pieces?
That’s exactly what the Pillar Content Strategy does.

Instead of creating new content daily, you:
- Record one high-value long-form content piece (a webinar, podcast, or deep-dive video).
- Break it into bite-sized social media posts, reels, LinkedIn articles, and carousels.
- Use AI to extract key insights, repurpose, and distribute content effortlessly.
- Build a system where your content works for you, not the other way around.

5 Actionable Steps to Get Started Today:

1. Host a 45-60 min webinar, podcast, or Q&A session on a topic your audience cares about. (This is your pillar content.)

2. Use AI tools like Submagic (for captions), Riverside FM (for high-quality recordings), and Flow AI (for repurposing).

3. Extract 5-10 short video clips (30-sec to 2-min) and turn them into reels for LinkedIn, Instagram, and YouTube Shorts.

4. Write 3-5 LinkedIn posts using key insights from your webinar. AI can help summarize and structure them.

5. Create a lead magnet (PDF, cheat sheet, or guide) from your content and add a CTA to capture emails.

💡 Why? Because content should be an asset, not a time-sucking burden. 
The more you systemize it, the faster you grow.

P.S. Have you tried repurposing content before? If not, what’s stopping you? 👇

question: How can I address concerns about losing followers on social media, though?
tweet_text:
If you're noticing a trend where people are unfollowing you, here are some positive steps you can take to engage your audience and perhaps even grow your following:

Content Quality: Focus on creating high-quality, engaging content that resonates with your audience. Think about what your followers enjoy or what they might find useful or inspiring.

Consistency: Regular posting can help keep your audience engaged. People are more likely to stick around if they know when to expect new content from you.

Interaction: Engage with your followers by responding to comments, asking questions, or starting discussions. This shows that you value their interaction and can make them feel more connected to you.

Understand Your Audience: Use insights or feedback to understand what types of content your followers are interested in. You might survey them or look at which posts get the most interaction.

Diversify Content: While maintaining consistency, try different formats or topics. Sometimes, people unfollow because they feel they've seen it all from you. Introducing something new can reignite interest.

Collaborations: Work with other creators or influencers who share your audience demographic. This can introduce your content to new viewers who might choose to follow you.

Value Add: Think about what unique value you offer. Perhaps you can provide insights, humor, inspiration, or educational content that's not easily found elsewhere.

Positive Vibes: Since you love praying for people and have a Christian faith, you might consider sharing uplifting messages or stories that align with your beliefs but appeal broadly.

Check for Unintentional Unfollows: Sometimes, people accidentally unfollow due to app glitches or confusion. You could gently remind your followers to check if they're still following you if you notice a sudden drop.

Don't Take It Personally: Remember, people's reasons for unfollowing can be very personal and not reflective of your content or value. They might be cleaning up their feed, have changed interests, or just need a break from social media.

By focusing on these strategies, you're not just aiming to stop people from unfollowing but also to create a community where people feel valued and connected. Remember, every unfollow can make room for someone new who will appreciate your content even more.

question: What does your heart guess about a successful marriage?
tweet_text:
Love makes us feel good.

It’s one of the most positive and powerful emotions we can experience. I mean who doesn’t want someone to take a genuine interest in them and care for them?

But love isn’t limited to just romantic relationships. It can be any type of love that offers social support, whether from friends, family, a place, a job, or even a pet.

However, to love is also to be vulnerable. It’s about opening your heart to something, which inherently involves risk. 

The emotional pain of love, when it goes unfulfilled or is lost, can be just as physical and intense as any injury. A broken heart is a very real medical disorder. This is why approach love with care, not fear. 

A secure person in love acts with confidence. They understand that love, at its core, is an act of courage and a  willingness to be vulnerable without the constant need for control or reassurance. A secure person:
🔘 Expresses their needs openly without shame or fear of rejection. They don’t hold back their feelings in an attempt to avoid losing other’s interest, but rather speak their truth with clarity, whether it’s about their relationships, work, or personal passions.
🔘 Recognizes inconsistency as a red flag and doesn’t feel the need to anxiously chase other’s attention. They don’t feel the obligation to “fix” others or to love harder in hopes of making up for the gaps.
🔘 Appreciates validation, but doesn’t depend on it. They don’t require constant reassurance to feel secure in the relationship, because their sense of self-worth isn’t based on other’s approval.
🔘 Sets boundaries with confidence, knowing that others will respect them. They don’t abandon their boundaries just because others may push back.
🔘 Chooses relationships or commitments that align with their values and where there is mutual willingness to give and receive love. They prioritize compatibility over chemistry.

Love is a beautiful thing, but it’s important to ensure that it doesn’t lead to heartbreak. 

Love is vulnerability, and vulnerability doesn’t equate to weakness or shutting your heart off. Love requires courage, and there can be no courage without vulnerability. True courage comes from the ability to show up and the confidence to be your full self, without the anxiety of trying to control the relationship.

question: How can I choose more relevant tweets to send?
tweet_text:
how to write posts that actually go viral? 🚀

the experiment: i analyzed top-performing posts in @KaitoAI  CT and broke down what makes them explode. turns out, crafting a high-engagement tweet isn’t just about luck – there’s a science behind it.

🤔 the goal: 
understand what makes a post hit the algorithm, trigger engagement, and get picked up by influencers.

the results: let’s get into it.

several factors determine whether your post takes off:

• your timing & topic selection
• your structure & readability
• your engagement triggers
• your use of tagging & networking
• random chance & external boosts

timing & topic selection ⏰
certain topics have built-in virality: ai, memecoins, retro drops, or high-profile debates.
you also need to post when the right people are online. most engagement happens within 30 mins of posting. if your tweet doesn’t pick up traction fast, it’s buried.

structure & readability 📜
if your post is a wall of text, no one reads it.
best formats? 🏆 bullet points & line breaks.
keep it punchy, skimmable, and high-impact.
✅ good example:
"why $IQ @IQ6900_ is the biggest sleeper play in AI 🔽"
❌ bad example:
"i think $IQ has potential because it's in the AI sector, and many projects like it have performed well historically."

engagement triggers 🎯
tweets that make people feel something always outperform neutral ones.
you need a bold take, a question, or an open loop.
examples that work:
🔥 "95% of traders fail – here’s how to be in the 5%"
🔥 "this memecoin is about to run 10x – but here’s the catch..."
🔥 "you’re sleeping on this airdrop. here’s why."

tagging & networking 🤝
posts get amplified when influencers interact.
strategic tagging = free reach.
biggest mistake? tagging random whales who never engage.
instead, tag people who actually interact.

random chance & external boosts 🎲
sometimes your post just needs an external push:
• engage with big accounts before posting (so they see your name)
• reply to trending tweets with your own insights
• drop a value-packed thread that people will bookmark

🎯 the results:
i tested 10 posts using these principles. 3/10 hit 10k+ views, and one got retweeted by a whale.

huge shoutout to @TheMoonMidas @Jeremyybtc @OX_DAO @craigscoinpurse @niqislucky @0xCheeezzyyyy @Carlitoswa_y @PhilOnChain @stikman @Smokey_titan @pparkdd @jayplayco @ParallelAiRev
for the inspiration.

key takeaways:

• write posts that spark emotion & discussion
• make your content skimmable & structured
• use strategic tagging & engagement
• test & refine – virality is a repeatable process

🗂️ experiment done. now, time to refine. end.

question: How does pressure bring concern into social media discussions?
tweet_text:
Navigating the expression of personal feelings, thoughts, and opinions requires caution, as sharing them can sometimes lead to unintended and severe consequences. In today’s world, many individuals prioritize their own emotions and viewpoints, and expressing dissenting opinions can provoke strong reactions. On social media, for instance, people may attack you with their words and platforms, attempting to rally others against you. Some individuals may even dedicate significant time to trolling, aiming to inflict emotional distress comparable to what they perceive your words have caused them, even if the pain you caused was unintentional.

In real life, disagreements can escalate dangerously, sometimes even leading to violence. Therefore, it’s wise to be discerning about with whom you share your innermost feelings, thoughts, and opinions, as it’s not always safe to do so. While sometimes it’s worth standing up for your beliefs, other times it’s better to prioritize your peace and personal safety.
